column4: now that I've figured how to do everything I want to do, I'm ready to give ubuntu the majority of my harddrive, what's the safest way to do this (a link with instructions would work just as well)
so you're trying to say you want the move the free space from your windows partition to the ubuntu?
I'd like to move the music files (which take up the most space) as well.
but you do want to resize the partitions which have files on them?
you can resize the partitions while preserving the data, but it takes a REALLY long time, a couple hours
I've done it many times
do I have to be present for those "couple hours"
no
I would BACKUP! BACKUP! BACKUP! any information you cannot afford to lose
then boot into the live cd. Under System->Administration-->Partition Manager you can resize your current partitions.
the first time I tried ubuntu half a year ago, I lost 180 gigs of info cause I "thought I knew what I was doing" (aka: being retarded)...so yeah I back up now
yes

I would recommend (Unless you want to preserver your current installs), reformat the entire drive, make 4 partitions, 1 NTFS (10 gb) for windows, 2 EXT3 (10gb) for linux install, 3 EXT3 (20-100gb depends on space) for /home, 4 linuxswap (512mb - 3 gb == equal to your ram).  Then install XP on the NTFS, then install ubuntu on the 2nd partition while setting the mount point of the 3rd partition as /home
then repeat the above instructions but with visat
When I was dual booting I setup my install like I specified above, and I've been very happy that I have a /home partition
I feel something just flew bye me, what is the advantage to that as opposed to resizing with the live cd?
resizing works fine (for the most part) but I;m a big believer in doing things cleanly. You're less likely to have problems and things will generally work better
Resizing will work, I've done it plenty of times
also...I don't have a vista cd. I got my laptop through my IBM discount, and it came with Vista installed.
then definately don't do a clean wipe.   Does vista have a built in partition manager>
then use that to SHRINK the windows partition, (Can vista handle EXT3?). Then use the live cd to grow your linux partition
I would say let vista resize the linux partition but I'm not sure how well the Vista partitioner will work with EXT3, MS doesn't have a lot of incentive to make things work with linux
so let the linux utility work on the linux partition
